Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase I: New polymers for 10% efficiency organic photovoltaic cells
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project aims to develop high efficiency polymers for organic photovoltaic cells (OPVs). OPVs based on polymers are ideal for environmentally-benign and affordable energy generation. However, the efficiency of OPVs is still low compared to their inorganic counterparts, currently at 7.9%. One of the major reasons is the lack of polymers with the required properties for a high efficiency device, such as strong and broad absorption, high carrier mobility, and appropriate energy levels. This project is expected to demonstrate 10% efficiency for OPVs through the following approaches, (1) design and synthesis of new conjugated polymers with ideal band gap, molecular energy levels, mobility, and processability; and (2) optimization of device structure, polymer film morphology, and interfaces. In this project, processes that will enable OPVs on flexible substrates will also be investigated.

The broader/commercial impact of this project will be the potential to result in high efficiency OPVs that are low-cost, flexible, and can be easily manufactured. This project is anticipated to benefit organic electronics industry by potentially replacing current battery technology in portable power source, thus limiting the use of toxic materials. Successful completion of this project will provide the possibility to achieve up to 7% solar module efficiency.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this Phase I of this STTR project, Solarmer Energy made significant progress in polymer development for high efficiency OPV cells. The research on polymers focused on benzodithiophene (BDT) - thienothiophene (TT) based polymer family. At the end of the project, a record power conversion efficiency of 8.41% was demonstrated for OPV cells based on fluorinated polymer BDT-FTT. This was achieved through systematically optimizing the BDT-TT system. The key approaches included: (i) modification of the solubilizing group in the polymer to maintain a good balance between polymer solubility and its p-p stacking; (ii) extending the conjugation system of BDT units; and (iii) tuning the polymer energy levels by functionalizing TT units with a series of substituent groups; and (iv) optimizing the device fabrication conditions using the new polymers. Ethylhexyl group was found to be excellent for extending the conjugation length in BDT-TT system. Thiophene-substituted BDT had a lower optical band gap and significantly better absorption. TT units with ester, ketone and fluorine atom units were synthesized and polymers were made by combining them with different BDT monomers to study the opto-electronic properties. Other device fabrication parameters such as donor acceptor ratio, film thickness, thermal treatment and solvent annealing conditions were optimized to achieve high efficiency OPV cells. Moreover, new phenomena were also observed during the polymer optimization. Slight modification of BDT functional group leads to significant change in polymer absorption and hence the cell efficiency. As an example, alkoxy-substituted BDT polymers exhibited high open circuit voltage (up to 0.9 V).

The 8.41% cell efficiency achieved in this project is the highest reported efficiency to the best of our knowledge. This, along with the fact that Solarmer has reported 4 world-record efficiencies in the last two years, establishes Solarmer polymer development program as the best in the world today. The results achieved in Phase I will provide useful guidance for future materials research work. In order to bring OPV technology closer to commercialization, more work needs to be done to further improve the cell efficiency, as well as to lower the module cost and increase the lifetime. Solarmer is continuing the efforts to make improvements in these areas.


Last Modified: 08/30/2011
Modified by: Yue Wu

Ethylhexyl group was found to be excellent for extending the conjugation length in BDT-TT system. Thiophene-substituted BDT had a lower optical band gap and significantly better absorption. In order to bring OPV technology closer to commercialization, more work needs to be done to further improve the cell efficiency, as well as to lower the module cost and increase the lifetime.
